ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In this class, you really get to develop your writing style, pick up style elements and ideas from other authors and pieces, and even learn a bit about how to look at other peers' writing and give feedback. It's not too reading heavy, so that way, you can just focus on writing.
Became a much better writer by understanding my style, which is important because nobody writes the same. This course gives you the liberty of writing whatever you like in whichever form you like.

I learned how to write concisely and in various styles. I also learned how to analyze the writing decisions, motifs, and styles of various other authors (both my classmates and the assigned readings). I became way more comfortable in experimenting with my writing, and also the value of peer review. This class really develops your writing skills, and does it in a very low stress environment. The papers were all pretty short (4 total papers that were 1500-1750 words), which taught me how to make each of my sentences matter.

I was able to work on my essay-writing weaknesses and improve on them. I also read a lot of good essays, which allowed me to pick out stylistic choices that I might be able to use in my own writing and apply new techniques to my writing.
How to close read different styles of essays and how to write essays with clarity

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I like how the course is structured around 4 essays: personal, social issue, profile, and place. Though the types of essays can overlap, it really helped to have one thing to focus on at a time. You get a week or two for the draft, and then another week or two for the final draft after reviewing feedback and making edits. I like that you get a good chunk of time to really focus on writing your essays. The small homework assignments are also very helpful too--unlike some classes where assignments can feel tedious and irrelevant.

Strengths are the essays that we read were incredible and also the writing prompts were narrow enough to be challenging but also broad enough to be creatively liberating. Weaknesses are thinking about the writing in a more systematic way (personally).

Strengths: very comfortable class structure. Seminars were very engaging and everyone was able to contribute in a meaningful way. The syllabus is clear and the assignments and expectations are made clear at the beginning of the class. Feedback on rough drafts were also very helpful and encouraging.

Strengths: Lizzie is an amazing teacher who gives very thoughtful feedback and who is always open for writing conferences or further clarifications on comments left on our papers. My classmates were also very open, thoughtful and kind to one another. It is also great that the class is in a seminar format, which allowed all of us to get comfortable with one another. Another strength was the writing prompts: memory/experience, social issue, profile, and place. They are all so broad, which gave us the freedom to truly express our thinking on paper. Another strength was that everyone in class was such talented writers, and you really get to read and soak in different writing styles.

Weaknesses: None really. The online format sometimes made it awkward when we ran into a dead-end in the discussion, but Lizzie did a good job with guiding us. I think this weakness is only because of COVID sadly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The best Zoom feature we used was the chat: sometimes we would be asked to find our favorite quote/sentence/writing style from a piece and type it into the chat and then go down the line unmuting and explaining why picked that sentence. It was really helpful for stimulating conversation when it seemed no one was all that inclined to unmute and answer an open-ended question.
Workshop sessions with the instructor worked very well.
Discussions still worked well and breakout rooms were effective

Open and frequent communication with students via announcements was very helpful for reminding us when our homework assignments were due. Most of the class materials, writing appointments, and discussion boards resided in Canvas, and Lizzie did a very good job utilizing the space given. All of the readings were easy to find, there was no confusion with due dates and it was nicely organized.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! Even if you're in STEM--no, ESPECIALLY if you're in STEM--you should take this course. 20/10 recommend, it will be the best writing credit class you take where you get so much out of it (as long as you put in the effort).
Yes, helps become a clearer writer/thinker.

Yes! This is such a fantastic course to help improve anyone's writing. I got to learn about the genre of creative nonfiction and now I feel more confident in my writing. I came in as a weak writer and wanted to improve my writing skills, and this course for sure has helped me. The instructor gave very helpful and constructive feedback and workshops with students were absolutely so helpful.

Yes, definitely take this course with Lizzie, she's an awesome teacher and the class is structured amazingly. There is also a good diversity in the readings, something that you don't see sometimes in other courses. Definitely take it if you want to improve your writing while being supported by both your classmates and teacher.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
